1006138358731505665.text: I'd love to hear about the things you apply every day to become a better manager. Let's help young leaders by sharing our experiences.

1006138355262910469.text: 5. Make mistakes possible. Your team won't always take your advice and that's okay. If it doesn't hurt customers, let it play out. If they fail then guide them towards a solution instead of saying "I told you so". If they win then the company wins. It's the best way to teach.

1006138353564209152.text: 4. Focus on the truth. Get your whole team to focus on doing what's right and not what's wanted, expected or assumed. It's great if a team member passionately fights for something. Just make sure they are quick to move on when proven wrong. (More: https://www.saffo.com/02008/07/26/strong-opinions-weakly-held/ …)

1006138351488036864.text: 3. Push everyone forward. Don’t accept things staying the same. Don't wait for permission to change. Nothing is true, everything is permitted. Listen to the critics. Then remember that only you get to decide how it governs your feelings. (More: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meditations ….)

1006138349906743296.text: 2. Lead with empathy. Be forgiving when someone messes up but knows it and solves it. Privately hold people accountable if failure isn't noticed or solved. Listen more than you talk. Say thanks a lot. Try and understand what truly motivates people and support them in it.

1006138348707237888.text: 1. Earn trust with transparency. Very rarely keep secrets. Externalize more than you're comfortable with. Then repeat it in different ways and often so different types of people will understand. Be open to your team and they’ll reward you with the same clarity.
